newsitem.title: CUBA: Cuba awards friendship medal to Canadian envoy.
newsitem.headline: Cuba awards friendship medal to Canadian envoy.

text.p: Cuba said on Thursday it had awarded a "Medal of Friendship" to outgoing Canadian ambassador Mark Entwistle in recognition of his work to strengthen ties between the two countries.

Entwistle, who is leaving Cuba on Friday after four years in Havana, was presented with the medal by deputy president Carlos Lage on Wednesday, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. Foreign Minister Roberto Robaina and parliament president Ricardo Alarcon attended the ceremony.
The statement said Entwistle had made a "valiant contribution to the strengthening of bilateral ties."
Canada says it wants to encourage change through dialogue with President Fidel Castro's communist government, rather than through confrontation.
Its stance has sometimes irritated the United States, which maintains an economic embargo on Havana and believes Cuba should be isolated as a means of pressure.

Canadian Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy made a brief official trip to Cuba in January, and the two countries signed a joint declaration agreeing to more cooperation in a range of areas, including human rights.

Cuba made clear at the time it preferred Canada's position to that of the United States or European Union, which has adopted a common position on Cuba including a clause under which improved relations depend on Havana making moves towards political and economic change.

Canada has become a leading business partner of Cuba since the early 1990s, Canadian firms are key investors, trade is worth about $400 million a year, and Canadian tourists were the largest group of foreign visitors to the island last year.
